statements.text: Robin Hood is famed as an outlaw in Sherwood Forest near Nottingham, stealing from proud lords and easing the hunger of the poor.
Folk say Robin Hood wore Lincoln green and carried a yew bow that could split another man's arrow on the butts at Nottingham.
The Sheriff of Nottingham rides the forest roads with men-at-arms, yet Sherwood Forest always seems to swallow his prey and spit him back in anger.
Maid Marian walks between Nottingham Castle and the green shade of Sherwood, passing secret words to Robin Hood and laughing at Prince John's spies.
In many tales, King Richard returns from war in the south and finds Robin Hood kneeling under the oaks of Sherwood, loyal in heart if not in law.
On a narrow bridge over a forest stream, Robin Hood and Little John trade blows with quarterstaffs until Robin falls in, and the two rise as sworn friends.
Friar Tuck is remembered as a stout, laughing priest who shares his ale with the Merry Men and scolds Robin Hood when pride grows too bold.
Will Scarlet, fine in red, and Much the Miller's Son keep watch on the forest paths, warning the Merry Men when the Sheriff's hunters draw near.
Ballads tell of a great archery contest in Nottingham where Robin Hood, in disguise, wins a golden arrow while the Sheriff rages and plots revenge.
Around firelit clearings in Sherwood Forest, the Merry Men share stolen coins and broken bread with beggars, widows, and wandering strangers.
In darker songs, Robin Hood dies at Kirklees Priory, betrayed by a false-hearted prioress, yet he still shoots one last arrow to mark his grave.
In cottages and taverns across Nottinghamshire, people still sing of Little John, Will Scarlet, Friar Tuck, and other Merry Men who followed Robin Hood against unjust rule.
